Minton, S. A., Jr. 2001. Amphibians & reptiles of Indiana. Revised second edition. Indiana Academy of Science, Indianapolis.

habitat_description:
The red-bellied mudsnake occurs along the Coastal Plain from southeastern Virginia to southern Florida, across Texas, and north in the Mississippi Valley to southern Illinois (Conant and Collins 1991; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Johnson 2000; Minton 2001; Mitchell 1994; Phillips et al. 1999; Tennant 1997; Trauth et al. 1994; Werler and Dixon 2000).

This species is described as a fossorial and semiaquatic snake that occupies creeks, low gradient rivers, shallow pools, springs, but also in riparian zones, herbaceous wetland, forested wetland, and scrub-shrub wetland.  Individuals can be observed in marshes, wetlands along the edges of large rivers, beaver ponds, sloughs with rotting logs, drainage ditches, swampy weedy lake margins, oxbow lakes, floodplains, and brackish tidal areas (Dundee and Rossman 1989; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Trauth et al. 2004; Werler and Dixon 2000). Burrows are usually found in fallen logs, leaf litter, soft soil, wet mats of vegetation along the edges of water bodies. The eggs are laid in an underground cavity, sometimes in alligator nests.

This snake occupies areas that are heavily vegetated and moist. It occurs in herbaceous, shrub-scrub and forested wetlands.
